abstract: As it seeks to bolster its flagging share price, General Electric may be willing to dispense with the business from which it sprang: the light bulb.
snippet: As it seeks to bolster its flagging share price, General Electric may be willing to dispense with the business from which it sprang: the light bulb.
lead_paragraph: As it seeks to cut costs and bolster its flagging share price, General Electric may be willing to dispense with the business from which it sprang: the light bulb.

headline.main: G.E. May Spin Off Its Consumer and Industrial Unit
headline.print_headline: G.E. May Spin Off Its Consumer and Industrial Unit

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: General Electric has agreed to sell its Japanese consumer-finance business to Shinsei Bank for 580 billion yen ($5.4 billion), according to reports citing undisclosed sources.
lead_paragraph: General Electric has agreed to sell its Japanese consumer-finance business to Shinsei Bank for 580 billion yen ($5.4 billion), according to reports citing undisclosed sources.

headline.main: Shinsei Buys G.E.’s Japanese Consumer-Finance Unit

abstract: NBC Universal, which has been in the news all week amid renewed speculation of a spin-off by General Electric, reported slight profit growth on Friday.
snippet: NBC Universal, which has been in the news all week amid renewed speculation of a spin-off by General Electric, reported slight profit growth on Friday.
lead_paragraph: NBC Universal, which has been in the news all week amid renewed speculation of a spin-off by General Electric, reported slight profit growth on Friday.

headline.main: Lower Costs Keep NBC Out Of GE’s Crosshairs For Now

abstract: Whew! General Electric met analyst’s forecasts Friday morning when it announced second-quarter earnings, after last quarter’s quasi-disaster, when G.E. missed badly. I guess that means Jeff Immelt get to keep his job as C.E.O. I’m being only mildly facetious.
lead_paragraph: Whew! General Electric met analyst’s forecasts Friday morning when it announced second-quarter earnings, after last quarter’s quasi-disaster, when G.E. missed badly. I guess that means Jeff Immelt get to keep his job as C.E.O. I’m being only mildly facetious.
